question: Question_05_(a)
statement:
Given the function

\[f(t) = \begin{cases}
0, & t<1 \\
2\pi, & 1 \leq t < 2 \\
\pi, & t \geq 2
\end{cases}\]

\textbf{(a)} Find the Laplace transform of \emph{f(t)}.
sols:
The Laplace transform, F(s), for a function f(t) is given by

\[F(s)=\mathcal{L}(f(t))=\int_0^\infty{}f(t)\exp(-st)dt.\]

Since our function is piecewise defined we can split up the integral and
write

\begin{align*}
F(s)&=\int_0^1f(t)dt+\int_1^2f(t)\exp(-st)dt+\int_2^\infty{}f(t)\exp(-st)dt\\
F(s)&=\int_0^10dt+2\pi\int_1^2\exp(-st)dt+\pi\int_2^\infty\exp(-st)dt.
\end{align*}

The first integral is just zero. For the second integral we get,

\[2\pi\int_1^2\exp(-st)dt=-\left.\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-st)\right|_1^2=-\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-2s)+\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-s).\]

For the third integral we get

\[\pi\int_2^\infty\exp(-st)dt=-\left.\frac{\pi}{s}\exp(-st)\right|_2^\infty=\frac{\pi}{s}\exp(-2s).\]

Adding the two integrals together we get

\[F(s)=-\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-2s)+\frac{2\pi}{s}\exp(-s)+\frac{\pi}{s}\exp(-2s)=\frac{\pi}{s}\left(2\exp(-s)-\exp(-2s)\right).\]
